loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en:
Taiwo A. is a hairdresser. She also sells hair materials like shampoo, hair extensions, hair cream, et cetera. She hopes to expand her business and she needs the loan amount of 70,000 naira (USD$475) to purchase more hair materials.

Taiwo is 38 years old and married with four children. She says thanks to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more hair materials.

loans.name: Sadio

texts.fr:
Madame  Sadio S. a 50 ans et vit à Gongebougou  un des villages de la préfecture de Kadiolo(Sikasso:troisième région administrtive de la république du Mali) avec ses 4 enfants et son époux  dans une famille traditionnelle élargie. 
Madame Sadio S. n’a pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle a appris à faire le petit commerce auprès de sa mère depuis l’enfance. Aguérrie par des années passées avec  de sa maman très expérimentée, elle mène  aujourd’hui son activité de commerce en compagnie de son mari lui même commerçant. 
Après trois prêts individuels tous correctements remboursés, elle est à son 4eme prêt individuel.
Madame Sadio S. compte acheter avec ce prêt, 15 sacs de maïs et 15 sacs de sorgho. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environants de Loulouni et de Nimbougou. Elle les revend au comptant aux marchés de Dallen, Nimbougou et Loulouni à une clientèle composée généralement d’hommes. 
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.500FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Ms. Sadio S. is 50 years old and lives in Gongebougou, a village in Kadiolo prefecture (Sikasso: third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) with her four children and spouse in a traditional extended family. She did not go to school for social reasons. During her childhood, she learned from her mother how to work in small-scale commerce. Battle-hardened through the years with her well-experienced mother, she now carries out her work in the company of her husband, a merchant himself.

After three individual loans, all correctly repaid, she is on her fourth one. She plans to use this loan to buy 15 sacks of corn and 15 sacks of sorghum. Supplies are gotten in the surrounding villages of Loulouni and Nimbougou. The goods are sold in cash at the marketplaces of Dallen, Nimbougou, and Loulouni, to customers composed generally of men.

She envisions realizing an average monthly profit of 12,500 francs CFA that will be used for the most part to augment her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain (corn and sorghum)

loans.name: Anvar

texts.en: Anvar is a hardworking entrepreneur from Isfara, Tajikistan. He has operated his own car repair business for the past 10 years. Anvar has extensive experience in this field and his skills are very much in demand. Car ownership is increasing rapidly in Tajikistan which means more business for repair technicians like Anvar. Anvar works hard to earn a good income and support his family. He and his wife have two children. Anvar has requested a short-term loan of $500 USD to buy some tools that he needs for his business. The income from this loan will help him pay for the schooling expenses for his children. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after the country’s independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing tools and spare parts used to repair cars

loans.name: Vincentia

texts.en:
Vincentia E. is married with one child and received an education through senior high school.

Vincentia sells gari and maize in Moree, near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2006. Her husband is a business man. Vincentia uses her income to pay for school fees.

Vincentia will use the loan to buy gari and maize, from Techiman, for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vincentia plans to give a quality education to her child.

loans.use: Buy food supplies for resale.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Ms. Adelaida E., 45 years old, is a single mom to her only child. She presently resides at Western Poblacion, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. Her business is a small grocery store that started with a capital of PHP 2,000. She is a good member of Paglaum and has established a good reputation in her neighborhood. She requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy stocks of canned goods, noodles, and other items for her store's inventory. She hopes to improve the condition of her life, with her child beside her.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of grocery items for her grocery store.

loans.name: Kofi

texts.en:
Kofi B. is 28 years old. He is married and has two children, both of whom are daughters. He says both of his daughters are in the primary school. He lives with his children and his wife in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Kofi works very hard to provide for the family. Kofi is a name given to a male born on Friday in the Akan tribe and other tribes in Ghana. His wife is a professional seamstress and a trader as well. Kofi is also a trader. He trades in yam. He buys tubers of yam from farmers in the nearby villages and supplies them to retailers and food vendors in his community. 
He has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure tubers of yam in bulk. He aspires to give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To procure tubers of yam

loans.name: Amal

texts.en: Amal is a 34-year-old married woman with two children living in Harrar, northern Lebanon. She has owned her own electrical goods store for one year but has 15 years of experience in the field. Today, Amal is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Aterei A Alungata Agnes Group

texts.en:
A. Agnes is 28 years old and married with three children of whom two are in school. More so, she is looking after one dependent who is also in school.

Agnes owns a retail shop and she has been operating in her retail business for over a year. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, maize, millet flour, salt, matchboxes, soap, cooking oil, etc., adding stock to meet her customers’ demands. Agnes is a hardworking businesswoman whose future prospect is seeing her children educated.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to meet her customers’ demands

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.en:
Maria Ines J. C. was born and raised in Boane, and continues to live there happily. She is 31 years old, and is married with two children, aged eight and ten. Maria studied through the 6th grade, but was forced to stop as her parents could not continue to afford to send her to school.

Maria works alone, selling products from a stand in Boane. Her best-selling products are peanuts and beans. With this loan she will help finance the purchase of construction materials for her home. This will be the first loan Maria has taken out with Kiva partner, Hluvuku-Adsema.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her home

loans.name: Ogundipe

texts.en: Ogundipe is 47 years old and married with six children. She sells drinks and provisions. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en: M. Rose is a very hard working and friendly 50-year-old lady and the leader of Tukwatire wamu group in Jinja. She is a business lady involved in knitting and supplying sweaters to schools and individual clients. She has been in the business for two years and at the start, she was given startup capital by a certain Non Government Organization in the form of a loan and it’s from that stage that she picked up on loans. However, this is her second loan with Pearl Microfinance and she hopes to grow her business more in future so that she can own a bigger workshop and even begin training others. She also strives for her children’s continued education for a better future. Rose needs a loan to be able to stock more threads for her business since even her previous loan helped to increase stock, which in turn brought in more profits for her children’s school fees. Rose is a married lady with six children aged 30  to 12 years. Four of then are still in school.

loans.use: To buy more threads for her sweater knitting business.

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Sustaining a business is not easy, but Mrs. Lucita S. is willing to put all her energies to securing the future of her children.

Lucita S. is 62 years old and is married with six grown children. She lives in Brgy. Ma-ao, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She grows a variety of vegetables which she also sells in the market, and this earns her about PHP 5,000 per month.

Lucita tells us that when NWTF-Project Dungganon started in their community, she joined without hesitation. She says that being part of the project has been enjoyable and interesting because she has learned how to appreciate what life is all about as an independent businesswoman. She also appreciates the camaraderie and support that Project Dungganon has provided her through what she describes as the almost rollercoaster ride of her life. She is thankful for the encouragement she has received to continue improving her business because it has motivated her to strive harder toward specific goals. For example, the income from her business has allowed her to start making improvements to her house, which she plans to continue with the income she earns as a result of taking out this new loan.

Lucita is borrowing PHP 7,000. This will be her twelfth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her goal is to sustain her business operations.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc., has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To obtain working capital to sustain her business

loans.name: Elvia

texts.es:
Elvia es una madre muy responsable de 36 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su pareja y sus 3 hijos. Ella se dedica diariamente al pastoreo de sus 200 ovejas, labor ardua, pero a la vez le gusta y es muy gratificante, ya que cada semana o quince días vende entre 4 ó 6 ovejas entre 80 y 120 soles, según el tamaño y si es macho el precio es mayor. Para ello, los compradores van hasta su casa para escoger al animal que necesiten. Por otro lado, su esposo reúne el guano de estos animales para utilizarlo en sus chacras de papa y olluco, y debido al uso de abono natural, sus productos son muy demandados, pues son más agradables. Es por ello que Elvia y su esposo trabajan muy contentos con sus labores agrícolas y ganaderas.
El deseo de esta trabajadora madre es de seguir trabajando con su banco comunal, es por ello que incursiona en su décimo préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA. Para lo cual, el dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de algunos insumos químicos para sus cultivos de papa, también comprará carneros machos para mejorar la raza de sus animales
texts.en:
Elvia is a very responsible mother, 36 years old, who lives in her own home together with her husband and their three children. She spends each day taking care of their flock of 200 sheep. This is arduous work, but she finds it enjoyable and very satisfying, because every week or two she is able to sell 4 to 6 sheep for 80 to 120 soles, depending on the animals' size and sex (males sell for a higher price). For these transactions, buyers come to her home and choose the animal they want. Her husband also collects the animals' droppings and uses them on their small farm, where they grow potatoes and ulluco [a root vegetable]. Thanks to the use of this natural fertilizer, their products taste better and therefore are in great demand. Because of all this, Elvia and her husband are very happy with their work in farming and ranching. The desire of this hard-working mother is to continue working with her communal bank, and thus she is entering into her tenth loan with the PRISMA microfinance organization. With the funds she is requesting, she will buy some chemical supplies for the potato farm, and she will also buy rams to raise the quality of her livestock.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies and breeding rams

loans.name: Yaotcha

texts.fr: T. G. Yaotcha est née le 01/01/1954 à Abomey. Yaotcha est mariée à ACCROMBESSI Avocè. Ce couple a à sa charge sept enfants tous scolarisés dont cinq sont les leurs. La famille réside depuis vingt ans à Fridjrossè Kpota, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Yaotcha vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Yaotcha vend des condiments de sauce (oignon, piments, ail, poivre, gingembre, gombo, sel, cubes, tomate en boîte et fraîche, huile végétal) et les vivres (haricot, farine de manioc, riz, maïs). C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Yaotcha achète ses produits et elle les vend chez elle à la maison. Yaotcha a déjà dix huit ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Yaotcha a eu deux crédits d’ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son activité. Pour  continuer à développer son activité, Yaotcha demande un troisième crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de condiments, de vivres et de divers (sardines, sucres, pâtes alimentaires…).

loans.name: Celeste Group

texts.es:
El grupo Celeste está conformado por tres productoras de ropa artesanal. Luz Marina M. comenzó desde muy joven en este trabajo, ella inicio cuando sus padres la inscribieron para que aprendiera bordado y costura, luego ella estuvo trabajando en talles de costura y después de mucho tiempo se independizo. 

De la misma manera Maura Antonia H. y Petronila L. comenzaron trabajando en talleres de bordado y costura y luego se independizaron y crearon cada una su taller.
Ellas invertirán el crédito en la compra de materiales como tela, hilos, cintas y bisuterías.

loans.use: para comprar tela, hilos, botones entre otros productos de satreria

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 59 years old and a married woman with four children. Currently all her children are fully independent. She sells frozen foods such as chicken, mutton, fish, sausages, etc. in the local market where she lives. She started this business a year ago. She takes delivery of stock from Kumasi in bulk and supplies to her customers. She does not have adequate funds to support her business. This has affected her operation, especially in the face of increasing food prices.

With the loan, she wants to purchase more cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, and pork to enable her to raise enough income to expand her sales. She dreams of being the number one supplier of frozen food in her community.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen foods like fish, chicken, mutton, etc.

loans.name: Ehen Bi Apuei Group

texts.en:
Mary is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. All of her children are in school thanks to the proceeds from her business. Mary is a seamstress and has been sewing for twenty years now. She is a specialist in female wears, and her skills and designs are of class. She sews a variety of styles which give her customers a new look, including kids school uniforms, church attire, kaba and slit, wedding dresses and funeral clothes. She would like to use the requested loan money to buy sewing supplies such as linen, thread and thimbles in order to increase her output and efficiency. Through her dedication and hard work she now has six apprentices; the quality training she provides will benefit them in their future endeavours. Mary hopes to increase her savings to provide her children with quality education. She needs the loan for the Christmas season so she will be able to increase her profits thanks to the increase in customer demand for dresses during this festive time. 

Mary is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Ehen Bi Apuei’. She is the one standing in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers. In this group, members act as guarantors for one another, providing social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay it. The group would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies to increase her output and efficiency.

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es:
La socia MARIA ELIZABETH pertenece al banco comunal “MERCAMUEBLE” y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. 

La socia tiene 29 años de edad, es conviviente, tiene dos hijos: un varón y una mujer. El hijo estudia en el jardín y la hija es aun un bebe. Ella tiene un pequeño negocio de fabricación y venta de muebles (taller de carpintería). 

Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la fabricación de muebles como escritorios, roperos, sillas, mesas, camas, etc. Ella ayuda a su esposo con la fabricación de muebles y con la venta de los mismos. La socia tiene un stand de venta de muebles en el mercado “MERCAMUEBLES” ubicado en el primer paradero del distrito de San Sebastián de la provincia del Cusco. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo.
       
La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de fabricación y venta de muebles, ella quiere comprar más materia prima (madera) y materiales para el acabado del muebles como tiner, laca, lijar, cola de carpintero, etc. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
María Elizabeth belongs to the Mercamueble Communal Bank. She lives in the Imperial city of Cusco. She is 29; in a common law marriage; and has two children, a son and a daughter. The son is in preschool, and the daughter is still a baby. She has a small business of making and selling furniture (carpentry shop). She alternates her activities between the home and making furniture like desks, wardrobes, chairs, tables, and beds, etc. She helps her husband make and sell the furniture. She has a furniture selling stand in the Mercamuebles Market, which is located at the first bus stop in the San Sebastián province of Cusco. She has been doing this for many years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She needs a loan to increase the capital in her business of making and selling furniture. She wants to buy raw material (wood) and materials like thinner, shellac, sandpaper, and glue, etc. for finishing the furniture. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it back on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital in her business of making and selling furniture

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora JUANA C. C. D. O. tiene  62 años, vive en el distrito D. Huanchaco, D. la provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad – Perú. 
La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal FUENTE D. VIDA, presenta estudios secunadrios completos y tiene 4 hijos quienes la apoyan eventualmente. 
La socia se dedica  a la compra y alquiler D. carros para taxi y con su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles comprò piezas y repuestos para darle mantenimientos a los 2 autos que tenìa.
Con su próximo crédito D. 1,000 nuevos soles comprará también repuestos para darle mantenimiento a los 3 autos que ahora tiene.
Juana sueña con aumentar su flota D. carros.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana C. C. D. O. is 62 years old and lives in the Huanchac district of Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a member of the Community Bank Fuente D. Vida [Fountain of Life]. She has a high school education and has 4 children who help support her from time to time. She works in the sale and rental of cars for use as taxis, and with her first loan of 300 Peruvian soles she bought spare parts in order to maintain the 2 cars that she had. With her next loan of 1000 Peruvian soles she will again buy parts to keep up the 3 cars that she now owns. Juana's dream is to expand her fleet of cars.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy spare parts for her cars

loans.name: Yasin

texts.en: Yasin D. was born in 1979. He has 2 children. He is an internally displaced person (IDP) from an Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli region, now settled Bala Bahmanli village in the Fuzuli region. Yasin has been in the butchery business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy meat to improve his butchery business.

loans.use: To buy meat

loans.name: Dorothée

texts.fr: V. Dorothée est née le 06 Février 1969 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Dorothée réside depuis 40 ans à Tonato, à Cotonou. Mariée à TCHENOU Théophile, un couturier, Dorothée est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Dorothée vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Dorothée est vendeuse de tissus à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Dorothée mène cette activité depuis cinq ans, une activité qui lui procure des revenus et lui permet de faire face à ses charges. Dorothée s’approvisionne à Missèbo à Cotonou, et à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Dorothée a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Dorothée souhaite que son étalage s’accroisse davantage. Mais actuellement, Dorothée éprouve de difficultés dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits. C’est la raison pour laquelle Dorothée sollicite un second prêt afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
V. Dorothée was born on February 6, 1969 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  For forty years, she has been residing in Tonato, in Cotonou.  Married to TCHENOU Théophile, a clothier, she is the mother of three children who are all in school.  She lives together with her children and husband.  Jointly, the couple ensures that family expenses are covered. Dorothée is a fabrics retailer at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has been in this business for five years, and it brings in the revenues that enable her to cope with expenses.  She stocks up on goods at Missèbo in Cotonou, and in Lomé, Togo, a country neighboring Benin.  Dorothée once obtained a loan from ALIDé and completed the repayment of it.  She wishes to expand her display of goods.  But right now, she is exhibiting some problems with supplies of her goods.  This is why she is requesting a second loan, so as to satisfy customer demands and to widen her field of business.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying lengths of cloth

loans.name: Mohamed A.'s Group

texts.en:
These gentlemen and ladies are staff members of a primary school in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone. This school was founded in 2002 and has a population of 109 pupils and 10 paid teachers.

This is the first loan this school is requesting from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not being able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Mohamed A. K. (second from left) is a teacher at the school and head of this group. Mohamed is a 42-year-old, married, with 6 children – 2 in secondary school and 4 in primary school. Mohamed was born in a village called Paki Masaboh about 5 miles away from Makeni city. He has been both a teacher and a businessman. He has taught for 15 years and has been in business for 30 years. He relies on the profit he makes out of his business to complement his monthly salary. Mohamed sells local produce like rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With his share of the loan, he will travel to villages surrounding Makeni to buy palm oil and rice wholesale to sell in Makeni.

(Attached beneath are snapshots of members of this group who were not available for a group photo.)

loans.use: Buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Manis Kasih Cooperative (Group C)

texts.en:
“Manis Kasih Women’s Cooperative” (Sweet Love) is a village banking organization located in Manistutu village, near the town of Melaya in north-west Bali. Manis Kasih was originally formed out of the initiative of mothers who, at the time, found it very difficult to obtain loans to develop their businesses. Local banks had numerous requirements that were quite burdensome to the women and thus made it difficult to secure loans. This group was formed to make loans more accessible to women in the region and, given its continued growth, became a legal entity in Bali in 2007.
At this time, Manis Kasih Women’s Cooperative has 126 members, all of whom are mothers of children of various ages. The group is located in a rural region of Bali, thus the majority of the women utilizing these loans work in agriculture as farmers, breeders or traders. Other women own small shops that sell daily goods such as rice, soap, etc. In this group, there are also a few women who harvest rice and one woman who makes cakes.
To meet the needs of its members and allow them to expand their businesses, Manis Kasih Women’s Cooperative is working with Mitra Usaha Kecil Koperasi (MUK) and Kiva to receive a loan fund that will be managed by group leadership in accordance with the rules the members have established. The leadership team pictured here will receive this loan and distribute it to a group of approximately 45 women who are all members of Manis Kasih. The loan money will allow the women to expand their respective businesses by buying new livestock, food or supplies for their animals, or by buying items to sell in their stores.
This subset of the Manis Kasih is headed by Ni Ketut G.. The group has requested a loan of 30,000,000 IDR. Ni Ketut G. manages a small shop in front of her home. Although her husband has a steady job in his village as an officer, Ni Ketut G. does not rely on her husband's fixed income. At the shop in front of her home, she sells all kinds of daily necessities such as rice, oil, writing equipment and various cakes and snacks. She is using her portion of the loan to purchase additional merchandise that she is lacking. This will help Ni Ketut G. earn extra income to supplement her husband's earnings.

Note to Kiva lenders
This group uses a community lending model (commonly referred to as Village Banking) that is very common throughout Asia. In this model, a select number of group representatives will take out a large loan on behalf of their entire group (often an entire village). They will then distribute and manage the loan and collect repayments for the lender. This is a common and efficient practice in the region, but it makes reporting on Kiva somewhat unusual. Unlike most other loans, Kiva’s partner MUK will be in contact primarily with the group leadership team who in turn will be overseeing the end borrowers. As such, journal updates likely will reflect the performance of the lending group rather than the individual end borrowers.
To learn more about Village Banking on Wikipedia, please copy and paste this URL into a new browser window: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Village_Banking

loans.use: To buy livestock to be bred, fattened and sold

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is a business lady based in Machakos. She provides a M-Pesa service (mobile-phone based money transfer service) to her neighbours. She has been running this business for two years. She also earns extra income through operating a pharmacy. Beatrice has requested for a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to add cash float to her mobile phone for M-Pesa. She hopes to work hard and open more branches. In 10 years, she wants to be driving and have grown to be wealthy. She describes herself as God-fearing, hardworking and caring.

loans.use: To add cash float to her phone

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
Sr. Santos Nacio en Pasla-Nor Cinti-Chuquisaca el 21 de Marzo de 1977, Concuvino (que no se casaron pero viven juntos) con la señora Celia, ellos tienen dos hijos hace 15 años que el señor trabaja como albañil.Su señora se encuentra trabajando en el mercado central de El Torno en la venta de ropa . El señor actualmente esta trabajando en una construccion, en El Torno Bolivia ( El Torno es la cuarta sección municipal de la provincia Santi Ivañez, del Departamento de Santa Cruz. Está dividida en cuatro cantones con 65 comunidades campesinas. De acuerdo al último censo realizado el año 2002, la población de El Torno alcanza a 40.000 habitantes.
Es una población joven, constituida por emigrantes venidos del interior del país: del occidente, quechuas, aymaras y de los valles del oriente, así como de las personas autóctonas.
Como característica de Santa Cruz, existen grandes diferencias sociales que conviven en un mismo espacio. Junto a grandes "quintas", propiedad de terratenientes y personas de mayor poder adquisitivo en Santa Cruz, conviven los propios habitantes de la zona, con construcciones mayormente sencillas (adobe y techo de motacú). Existe una diferencia entre las poblaciones de Santa Rita y Santa Marta 1 y Santa Marta 2, que se encuentran al borde de la carretera antigua a Cochabamba, donde se encuentran viviendas de ladrillo y teja junto a las más sencillas, y las poblaciones campesinas que se encuentran hacia el interior de la montaña, que son puramente de adobe y motacú, con condiciones mucho más sencillas, donde no llegan el agua y la luz.
Estas poblaciones se encuentran a una distancia de entre 5 y 20 kilómetros hacia el interior (en la zona pastoral que deben atender los voluntarios). Dicha zona pastoral está compuesta de 9 comunidades, a las que se accede por caminos de tierra por los que a veces pasan vagonetas para poder acceder a ellas.
La economía de la población se basa en la producción agropecuaria y frutícola, así como el trabajo de extracción de piedra, ripio y arena del río Piraí que circunda a todo el municipio. También existe una gran actividad de comercio, especialmente en la población de El Torno, donde se instala el mercado en que se venden los productos del trabajo campesino).

El cliente esta agradecido con la institucion por el apoyo  que se le a brindado ya que podra comprar un poco de material de trabajo y herramientas como ser flotacho, pala y otras cosas mas.
texts.en:
Santos was born in Pasla-Nor Cinti-Chuquisaca on March 21st, 1977. He lives with Celia, and they have two children. He has worked as a bricklayer for 15 years. Celia works selling clothes in the central market in El Torno. Santos is currently working on construction in El Torno, Bolivia. (El Torno is the fourth municipal section in the Santi Ivañez province in the Santa Cruz department.) It is divided into four cantons with 65 rural communities. According to the 2002 census, the population is up to 40,000 inhabitants. It is a young population made up of emigrants coming from the interior of the country, from the west, Quechuas, Aymaras, and people from the eastern valleys like the Autóctonas. Santa Cruz can be characterized as having great social differences existing in the same area. Large “quintas”, property of landowners acquired in Santa Cruz, and people with greater power co-exist with the area’s own inhabitants who live in more modest houses (adobe with roofs made of palm fronds). A difference exists between the populations of Santa Rita, Santa Marta 1, and Santa Marta 2. These places can be found on the border of the old road to Cochabamba. You can find houses there that are made of brick and tile along with more modest houses. There are also rural populations, which can be found towards the interior of the mountain. The houses there are solely made of adobe and palm fronds under more modest conditions. They do not have water or electrical services. These populations can be found between 5 and 20 kilometers towards the interior (in the pastoral region the volunteers need to take care of). This pastoral zone is comprised of nine communities, which can be accessed by dirt roads. Sometimes trucks are used to be able to access the communities. The population’s economy is based on farming, fishing, and growing fruit. People also work at extracting rocks, debris, and sand from the Piraí River, which surrounds the entire municipality. There is also great commercial activity, especially in El Torno. A market is set up in El Torno, and farm products are sold there. He is grateful to the institution for the support they have given him. He will be able to buy a few more work materials and tools such as a trowel, a shovel, and other things.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tools and materials

loans.name: Kiki

texts.en:
Kiki A. is 42 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children who all go to school. She is currently in the business of selling bedsheets in her shop, and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue sending her children to school.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for the production of jewelry and agricultural tools.

loans.name: Buen Corazon Group

texts.es:
Graciela C. es integrante de la Asociación Comunal Buen Corazón  que a su vez pertenece al Centro Focal Exaltación, tiene 22 años y es vecina de la ciudad de El Alto, está con su grupo hace 2 años aproximadamente por invitación de sus amigas. 
Graciela elabora ruanas (son ponchos largos) hace 5 años aproximadamente, adquirió la habilidad de tejar ayudando a sus padres que también se dedican a la misma actividad, ahora necesita el préstamo para comprar materia prima.
Las demás integrantes de esta  Asociación tienen actividades económicas como: la venta de jugo, juguetes, perfumes, ropa, y otros. 
Todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima, según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
Graciela C. is a member of the Good Heart Community Association, which in turn belongs to the Focal Point Exaltation group. She is 22 years old and is a neighbor of the city of El Alto. At the invitation of her friends, she joined the group about 2 years ago. Graciela has been making “ruanas” (which are long ponchos) for about the last 5 years, She acquired the ability to knit by helping her parents who are in same business. She needs the loan to buy raw materials. The other members of this Association engage in economic activities such as: selling juice, toys, perfumes, clothing, and other items. All of the members need a loan to buy merchandise, supplies or raw materials, according to the businesses they have.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Pov's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov H. is 34 years old and is a villager who lives in Preak Ta Pov village in Kandal province. She is the leader of this group loan who has been selected by its four members. Each member will use the loan to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Pov H. is a beautician at home while her husband, Mr. You Nos Makk, is a construction worker. With these two positions, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Aside from being a construction worker, Mr. You Nos Makk is also a musician who performs at wedding ceremonies.

Mrs. Pov H. is now requesting a loan to buy beautician supplies to support her business. This couple has two children: one is a attending the local school while the youngest one is just 8 months old.

loans.use: To buy beautician supplies

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma S. has successfully paid her first Kiva loan! With the loan, she purchased more piglets, grew them and already sold them in the market. She is so thankful for your support and the opportunity to borrow money from Kiva. Norma is very happy that she was able to buy and sell the animals without delay because of the loan. She wishes to access a larger loan to expand her hog-raising business of buying and selling of pigs so she can earn more profit. Norma thanks Kiva for providing her with opportunity to increase her income. Your support is important to her family and they are very grateful. Norma’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of shortage. Over the years, she has provided for her family by other work involving hog raising, including slaughtering and tending to farming business in her village. Now she is proposing another Kiva loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos for hog fattening, a common business for people in her area suffering from poverty. Norma will buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale. With the support of ASHI, a Kiva partner, she is hopeful that her hog-fattening business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets, sacks of feed and supplements and vitamins for the piglets

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz I. is from the village of Anito, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Luz is married and has 4 school-aged children. Luz owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Luz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Iva

texts.en:
Iva T. is 21 years old. She is married and has one 1-year-old child. Iva grows and sells fruits and vegetables. She has 1 year of experience in this business.  

Iva needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase vegetable seeds and fertilizer.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 100 talas or US $42 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Iva joined SPBD. This is her 1st loan from SPBD. SPBD's loans are Iva's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds and sacks of fertilizers

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia T. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Emilia is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Emilia raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emilia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Emilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the first loan taken out by Emilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Nadhra

texts.en:
Nadhra is a married woman with two boys, 14 and 10 years old, who both attend school. Her husband is employed and he contributes to the family’s basic needs. Nadhra owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses are food, electricity, clothing and school fees.

Nadhra has been operating her business of selling soft drinks for the last five years. She sells by going from door to door and also sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of competition in her business.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to start another business of buying handbags and shoes wholesale and selling them retail. Her major goal is to own her own shop in future.

Nadhra decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To purchase handbags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is an active member and secretary of the Kenyagoro Chepkole Group in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years and sells his milk and tea to the local market. He is a full-time farmer and solely depends on the income from his farming to provide for the basic needs of his family.

Samwel has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will help pay school fees for his children and this will raise their standards of living. His biggest challenges have been difficulty in finding the right type of breed and that the veterinary services available are not reliable. In five years time, he would want to have improved his dairy farming by keeping the right dairy breeds and building them modern dairy units.

Samwel is 43 years old and married with eight children between the ages of 5 and 20. All the children attend school.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Wilder

texts.es: Wilder, de 25 años, es soltero y no tiene hijo alguno. Reside en la localidad de Quimbiri, ubicada en la ceja de la selva peruana, donde tiene su propio techo a base de madera. Wilder, es un joven que le gusta explorar cosas nuevas. Es así que incursiono en la actividad agrícola, específicamente al cultivo y comercialización de piña y café, en donde viene consolidándose en su localidad, incluso su margen de ventas va en aumento, esto es debido a la calidad de sus productos y al precio competitivo que ofrece. Trabaja en conjunto con su familia, en donde le brindan su apoyo incondicional, pero en temporada de cosecha tiene a cargo de sus peones con la necesidad de que los pueda facilitar la extracción de su producto final, siendo llevados al  mercado de si zona. Anhela tener su propia tienda de venta de celulares, con la finalidad de obtener más ganancias y cambiar su estilo de vida. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma de pagos, además está orgulloso de pertenecer al banco comunal, debido a la solidaridad que existe en los socios. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de insumos y abono, para que le brinde un cuidado respectivo a sus plantaciones de café.
texts.en:
Wilder is 25 years old and single without any children. He lives in his own wooden house, in an area called Quimbiri, located near the Peruvian jungle. Wilder is a young man who likes to explore new things. This is how he began to work in agriculture, specifically in the cultivation and sale of pineapples and coffee. His sales and profits have been increasing thanks to the quality products he sells and the competitive pricing he offers. Wilder works together with his family, who give him unconditional support. However, in harvest time he hires laborers to pick and transport the goods to the market. Wilder's goal is to one day open his own shop to sell mobile phones, and be able to earn enough money to change his lifestyle. This is his six loan with MFP, and he commits to continue with his timely payments. He is proud to be a member of the communal bank where there is a strong sense of solidarity among the members. With the loan he is requesting, Wilder will purchase supplies and fertilizer to care for his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies and fertilizer for his coffee and pineapple crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her dairy and banana farming

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn P. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for sale and also buys and sells bananas. She has been engaged in her businesses for over three years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. 

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to renovate the existing shelter for her livestock. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to renovate existing shelter for her livestock

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es:
Wilfredo de 40 años de edad, tiene 1 niña de 5 añitos, su esposa es comerciante, el cual lo ayuda con los gastos familiares y con los compromisos adquiridos, habita en la zona # 3 del Municipio de Nueva Guinea; labora para el CETA  INATEC  desde hace 4 años desempeñandose con gran responsabilidad y honestidad como inspector.  

El Ingeniero M. se siente bien agradecido con la instituciòn ya que este seria el segundo crèditos otorgados por Kiva por lo que se ha sentido apoyado y  ha mejorado su vivienda y sus condiciones  de vida  Este crédito lo requiere para reparar la cocina  y de esta menera mejorar poco a poco su vivienda. 

Su mayor sueño en la vida es seguir estudiando para vivir actualizado , tener estabilidad laboral para asi ayudar a su linda familia.
texts.en:
Wilfredo, 40, has a five year old daughter.  His wife is a merchant who helps him with family expenses and other acquired economic responsibilities.  He lives in Nueva Guinea’s Zona #3.  He has worked honestly and responsibly as an Inspector for CETA INATEC for the last four years.

Engineer M. is very grateful to the institution because this will be the second Kiva loan he’s been granted.  He has felt much supported and has improved his home and living conditions.  This loan is needed to repair the kitchen thereby gradually improve his home.

His greatest dream in life is to continue studying so that he can be up to date and have stable employment in order to help his lovely family.

loans.use: For kitchen repairs.

loans.name: Yuliana Milagros

texts.en:
Yuliana is twenty-nine years old. She resides with her partner and two children in the district of Saña near the city of Chiclayo. They live in the small town of Centro Poblado Menor Saltur, which is a congregation of homes.

For the past two years Yuliana has raised ducks, chickens and other small to medium sized animals on the land behind her home. This business helps mitigate fluctuations in the family income and provides extra income for the family.

This will be Yuliana’s first loan from Edpyme Alternativa. She plans to use the funds to purchase additional balanced feed for the animals to provide ongoing management of her business and increase the family income. She dreams of being able to put her children through a full course of schooling and, possibly, to send them to university.

loans.use: To purchase additional balanced feed

loans.name: Pio Xii Group

texts.es:
El grupo Pio XII está conformado por cinco personas trabajadoras una de ellas es Zoila R. de 51 años quien se dedica al comercio de nacatamales, comida típica a base de masa y cerdo que se consume generalmente los fines de semana.
Ella con el crédito compra el credo y surtirá su pequeña venta de golosinas. 
Los otros integrantes del grupo son  Melenciana Gaitán quien vende tortillas, frito y chiverias, Sara M. tiene una pulpería, Zenovia M. desde hace 4 años tiene una modesta venta e Ignacio de Jesús J. quien fabrica hojas para tamales, yoltamal y tamales.
texts.en:
The Pio XII (Pius XII) group has five members.  One of them is Zoila R., 51, who sells nacatamales, a typical dish made from dough stuffed with pork that is usually consumed on weekends.

She will use the loan to buy pork and to stock her small snack sales business.

The other group members are: Melenciana Gaitán who sells tortillas, snacks and yoghurt snacks, Sara M. who has a grocery store, Zenovia M. who has had a modest sale for the last four years, and Ignacio de Jesús J. who makes leaves for different kinds of tamales.

loans.use: For pork, corn, firewood, tomatoes, potatoes, etc.

loans.name: Leonardo Rafael

texts.es:
Leonardo Rafael V. B. tiene 29 años. Es casado vive con la esposa y con el hijo,  en el cantón de San Miguel en la Provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 2  hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. YAGUI GRANDE se encuentra ubicada A 30 minutos de la Oficina San Miguel, perteneciente al cantón San Miguel, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz y papas, esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Leonardo se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y papas. Compra sus productos en Ambato y San Miguel y los vende en la feria de San Miguel los días jueves.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz y papas. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar un carro para los padres.

Le gusta hacer deporte y el carnaval.
texts.en:
Leonardo Rafael V. B. is 29 years old.  He is married and lives with his wife and children in San Miguel canton, in Bolívar province.  He has two children.

The Yagui Grande solidarity group is located 30 minutes from our San Miguel office, in San Miguel canton.  The members of this group work in short-cycle agriculture, growing corn and potatoes.  They have been doing this for a long time.

Leonardo is a farmer.  He grows corn and potatoes.  He buys his products in Ambato and San Miguel and sells them in San Miguel market on Thursdays.

He is requesting this loan to buy farming supplies and fertilizers for his corn and potato crops.  The support of this loan will help him financially to cover his needs.  He faces challenges such as insect infestations, diseases and changes in the weather.  His dream is to buy a car for his parents.

He likes to take part in sports and celebrate Carnival.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena G. is from the village of Kilikili, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 27 years old. Rowena is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk food in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk food & canned goods. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like junk food & canned goods

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily A. O. is 37 years old, widowed and has four children aged between 5 and 15. She hopes to give her children a quality education to university level. Her business is located at Nyalenda in Kisumu. Kisumu is the region in Kenya known for fish production from Lake Victoria and is well known as the lake basin. 
Emily owns a salon where she does ladies' hair. She has been in this business for six years now. She says that her business is profitable and the only major challenge she faces is lack of equipment due to financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy salon equipment to meet customer demand. She hopes to expand her business in the future. Emily describes herself as an honest and humble lady.

loans.use: To purchase salon equipment

loans.name: Norma  Maria

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal” SUMAC SONCCO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Norma María; ella tiene 57 años de edad, casada y tiene 3 hijos; La socia se dedica a su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, ella vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche entre otros productos más la socia lleva años con este su negocio el cual le está yendo muy bien y espera poder seguir asi, la socia mediante este negocio saca a su familia adelante ella es una buena persona alegre, optimista y con 
muchas ganas de seguir adelante.

La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar más mercadería para su negocio para poder abastecer a todos sus clientes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota
texts.en:
Norma Maria belongs to the SUMAC SONCCO Communal Bank. 

She is 57, married, and has 3 children. She has a grocery store where she sells basic staples such as rice, sugar and milk, among other items. She has had this business for several years and it is going very well. She hopes to be able to continue, as she uses this business to get her family ahead. She is a good, happy and optimistic person with a great desire to succeed.

She is requesting this loan to purchase more merchandise for her business in order to provide everything that her customers want.

She is happy to have this loan and promises to honour the payments of her quotas.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise for her business in order to supply the needs of all of her customers.

loans.name: Lieu

texts.en:
Lieu T. H. is 51 years old with 4 children. Two of them attend high school. She has lived in Tuan le for a long time, and because it is an area known for its land and producing clean vegetables, she is an experienced farmer. She has a paddy of 3,600 square meters, in which high quality kinds of vegetable are grown. Every month, she can earn 3,000,000 VND profit from selling these products.

She has been a client of Seda credit program since 2004, and is a good borrower. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy fertilizer and seeds to prepare for the next crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds to prepare for next crop.

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en:
Celsa P. is from the town of Surallah. She is 51 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Celsa raises crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Celsa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Celsa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Martha Rosa

texts.es:
Martha es una pequeña comerciante, que inicio sus ventas hace cuatro años, en la venta de granos básicos y carne de cerdo, con ayuda de su esposo quien labora como comerciante.
Sus ventas comienzan a dar un giro diferente al aumentar la variedad de productos con financiamiento que Afodenic otorga mediante cuatro ciclos que ha trabajado, en donde comienza hacer comida rápida, venta de gaseosas, refrescos entre otros.
Lo que quiere seguir invirtiendo para un futuro mejor de su familia, lo que con este nuevo préstamo comprara: salchichas, pastas para preparación de hotdog, hamburguesa, fritanga, refrescos, gaseosas en donde vende en su carrito cada día.  Y que espera seguir ofreciendo a sus clientes más calidad de productos.
texts.en:
Martha is a saleswoman who started selling products four years ago.  She started out selling basic grains and pork with the help of her husband who is also a salesman.

Martha's sales started taking a different turn as she increased her range of products through loans she received from Afodenic over four loan cycles.  She started selling fast food, sodas and soft drinks.

Martha would like to continue investing so that she can offer a better future to her family.  She will use this new loan to buy sausages and other ingredients for making hot dogs, burgers and fried snacks.  She will also buy soft drinks and sodas which she sells on her small cart every day.  Martha hopes to continue offering her customers better quality products.

loans.use: to buy food products for making burgers and hot dogs, soda, etc.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana lives in a small city of Punjab Pakistan called Kasur. it is famous for its leather industry. She has been living in a 3-roomed brick house with her family in the area of Kot Fateh Baz Khan for the past 18 years. 

Rehana is an embroidery expert and does embroidery on clothes for her neighboring customers. She has a good name in the region due to her ability to produce quality work. She receives regular orders every month, which earns her good income. She uses this income to pay utility bills. Her husband, M. I., operates an herbal medicines business. He has good knowledge about herbs and, not only treats the patients, but also sells the medicines to those who do this business in different cities. 

Rehana is the mother of 7 children. Her eldest son is 17 years old. He left his education after 5th level and started doing work. He operates a power loom machine and manufactures clothes. Her elder daughter helps Rehana in the embroidery business. The daughter is going through with the learning process and, after some months, will be handling it independently. The other 3 children are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education and remain living at home. 

Rehana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. Through the loan, he will buy larger quantities of herbs for making medicines to treat his patients better. Rehana is hopeful that the loan will help her husband increase his profits and serve more patients. 

Rehana is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rehana”.

loans.use: To buy herbs for herbal medicines business.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SANTA ROSITA DE AYLLUPAMPA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Marcelina; ella tiene 42 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de animales menores como gallinas, chanchos y cuyes la socia vende en forma ambulatoria en el mercado de la provincia de Urubamba, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de animales. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar chanchos, gallinas y cuyes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Our associate is a member of the “Santa Rosita de Ayullupampa” communal bank, located in the Urubamba district and province, within the Cusco department.    Marcelina is 42 years old and has four children.  She sells small animals such as chickens, hogs, and Guinea pigs.  She does not have a fixed location from which to sell, but sells in the Urbamba province market.  She wants to expand her business and is asking for this loan in order to buy hogs, chickens, and Guinea pigs.

She is happy about the loan and is committed to making her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy small livestock for resale

loans.name: Candelaria De Jesus

texts.es:
Doña Candelaria, se dedica a la venta D. ropa, tiene 44 años D. edad y 10 años D. tener el negocio, lo tiene ubicado en el mercado municipal D. El Transito, tiene casa propia donD. vive con su esposo y un hijo.
Ella solicita un préstamo para la compra D. mercadería, ya que quiere surtir el negocio en blusas, faldas, short, y todo lo relacionado al verano. Con esta compra espera tener mayor afluencia D. clientes y poder satisfacer sus gustos.
Su aspiración es tener mejores ventas y aumentar la clientela, ir creciendo como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Candelaria works selling clothing. She is 44 years old and has had this business for 10 years. It is located in the city market of El Transito. She has her own home where she lives with her husband and son.

She is asking for a loan to buy merchandise, since she wants to stock blouses, skirts, shorts, and other summer items. By buying these products she hopes to attract more customers and proviD. what they desire. Her dream is to increase sales and attract more customers to keep growing as a small-business owner.

loans.use: buy blouses, skirts, shorts, and other summer items

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
Ana Maria works hard to support 3 children. She is married and has a butcher shop business.  Ana Maria requested a PHP 1,800 loan through NWTF to buy an Envirofit cookstove.  She is getting the Envirofit cookstove because it needs less fuel to cook food than the firewood that she buys.  She wants the firewood to last longer.

Ana Maria is aware that, by using the Envirofit cookstove, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to purchase an Envirofit cookstove

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 43-year-old married man with three children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His wife is a teacher by profession and their dream is to educate their children through university. He has been farming for three years and reaping tangible benefits despite challenges in seasons and the high prices of seedlings. He started with the money borrowed from Hofokam and he has been able to buy land and farm extensively. His dream is to specialize in mechanized agriculture. Stephen needs the loan to hire a tractor and buy seedlings.

loans.use: To hire a tractor and buy seedlings

loans.name: Sulaina

texts.en:
Sulaina is 21 years old and lives in Uganda. She is married and has no children. Sulaina has a business selling coffee, which she has run for three years. She also has a second business selling vegetables.
To help expand her business, Sulaina has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more coffee for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Sulaina hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.
Sulaina is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving the lives of women. As a girl, Sulaina feels happy that she is able to provide everything on her own.

loans.use: to purchase more coffee for resale.

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SR. DE TAYANCANI”; La socia vive en el distrito de Ocongate en la provincia de Quispicanchis,  departamento del Cusco.

La  socia Dora; tiene 34 años de edad; la socia tiene 5 hijos y ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la venta de comidas caseras típicas de la región;  la asocia elabora sus comidas típicas en su casa y los lleva a vender en la plaza principal del poblado de Ocongate, junto a sus otras compañeras de banco comunal y vecinas de trabajo;  la socia  suele llevar platos diferentes a las de sus compañeras para que no tengan competencia, ellas se ponen de acuerdo y varían sus menús diarios; la socia desea el crédito para invertir en la compra de insumos tales como arroz, aceite, sal y otros ingredientes.

La socia valora y agradece infinitamente el crédito otorgado ya que este le permite crecer con su negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida, así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
Dora is a member of the "Sr. de Tayancani" community bank.  She lives in Ocongate district, in Quispicanchis province, in Cusco department.

Dora is 34 years old and has five children.  She divides her time between her household chores and her business selling home-made meals that are typical of her region.  She makes the meals at home and takes them to sell in the main square in the village of Ocangate, together with the fellow members of her community bank and those who work in the same area.  Dora usually makes different dishes to those of her friends so that they don't cause competition for each other.  They come to an agreement and vary their daily menus.  Dora would like this loan to invest in buying supplies such as rice, oil, salt and other ingredients.

Dora values her loan and is infinitely grateful for it since it will allow her to grow her business and improve her quality of life.  She therefore pledges to make her repayments according to schedule.

loans.use: to invest in buying supplies such as rice, oil, salt and other ingredients

loans.name: Rafael

texts.en:
Rafael requires a loan to buy diverse inventory, such as pants, shoes and women's clothing. He also sells passion fruit after he seeds them, and they are really for wholesale. He has been running his business for four years. Rafael lives in the Hato Mayor region of the Dominican Republic, located in the eastern part of the country. Hato Mayor is a fairly mountainous region where the principal industry is agriculture. 

Rafael has taken out four loans with field partner Esperanza International over the past two years; all of which have been paid back in full. He has used these loans to diversify the products that he sells. He is very excited about taking out this loan so that he can continue to grow his business.

Rafael says that his favorite thing is to work in the country, and his most important challenge is to build a house for his family. He hopes that with his business profits he will be able to save and make his dreams come true.

loans.use: to buy pants, shoes and women's clothing.

loans.name: Tith

texts.en: Tith is a construction worker. His wife works in the factory and their combined income is $5. Tith has 6 children; three are studying and one is working. Every month, Tith spends $20 on food, $10 on electricity, $10 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. He would like to request a loan of $500 to buy fertilizer and seed in order to farm in the rainy season. He hopes to earn more income by farming in the rainy season.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed

loans.name: Sylvie Soudéa

texts.fr: Sylvie Soudéa est âgée de 35 ans et est mariée à Léonce, un architecte. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge. Sylvie Soudéa et son mari assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Sylvie Soudéa vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Après avoir arrêté l'école au cours secondaire, Sylvie Soudéa mène comme activité la vente charbon de bois au Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Sylvie Soudéa mène cette activité qui lui procure des revenus l'aidant à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Sylvie Soudéa achète ses produits auprès des grossistes au Bénin et les revend à son domicile. C’est la cinquième fois que Sylvie Soudéa sollicite un financement auprès de ALIDé, en vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Les crédits obtenus précédemment ont été tous bien remboursés.
texts.en: Sylvie Soudéa is 35 years old and married to Léonce, an architect. The couple have five children, all in school and in their care. Sylvie Soudéa and her husband provide for the family together. Sylvie Soudéa lives together with her husband and children. After having ended her studies at the secondary level, she began running a business selling charcoal in Benin. She has run this business for about ten years, and it provides her with an income that helps her provide for the family. She buys her products from the wholesalers in Benin and re-sells the goods at her house. This is the fifth time she is seeking a loan with ALIDÉ in order to raise the level of her business and better satisfy the demands of her clientele. All of her previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is a rice farmer who is engaged and has no children.  She has been a farmer for the past six years, and she learned rice farming from a formal training program.

She will use her Kiva loan to support labor costs during rice production: nursery, transplanting, field management, guarding from birds, and then in harvesting activities.

With profits from her farming she wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. 

For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To cover labor costs during rice production.

loans.name: Por Fe Vivimos Group

texts.en:
Clara is one of the members of the Group Por Fe vivimos 1, 2 & 3 (By Faith we live), located in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, where the primary economic activities are commerce, industrial cement plants, and household and cosmetic products. Clara makes bags of food, with many different meals and then she sells them for biweekly payments according to the days of most companies; payment days. People make credit purchases and then pay her in one or two payments during a month. With this loan, she is planning to buy ingredients for different meals to prepare the food packages.

This is Clara's 11th loan. She has been taking loans for about seven years and has successfully repaid all her previous loans. She started her business after she took her first Esperanza loan. With her business and the loans, she has increased her income and capital to improve her business and her life. She is a divorced mother with two children. She cares for and works for their needs. 

Clara's dream is to continue improving her business. She is planning to reinvest her profits in the business and save. She thanks all of you for your support!!

loans.use: to buy rice, cooking oil, canned meals, sugar and seasoning.

loans.name: Guillermo Ramon

texts.es: Guillermo Ramón tiene su negocio que es la venta de mariscos. Hace más de 15 años que tiene este negocio. Fue por su Mama que el logro aprender este medio de vida, el obtiene más clientes de manera ambulante por lo que tiene  que alistarse todos los días para salir muy temprano y ofrecer la variedad de productos que le solicitan. El crédito es para la compra de camarones, pescado, punches, jaibas, concha, chuletas entre otros mariscos.
texts.en: Guillermo Ramón has a business selling seafood.  He has had this business for more than 15 years and learned the trade from his mom.  He gains most customers working as an itinerant vendor and has to get ready to go out very early every morning to sell the variety of products that his customers request.  He will use this loan to buy shrimp, fish, 'punches', crabs, shellfish, 'chuletas' and other seafood.

loans.use: to buy shrimp, fish, 'punches', crabs, shellfish, 'chuletas' and other seafood

loans.name: Dieu Plus Fort Limonade Group

texts.fr:
Amboise  est le coordinateur de son groupe Dieu plus fort.
Il n`est pas marié et il a 4 enfants.

Amboise habite dans la région nord d’Haiti où de l’électricité est rare et de l’eau est très limitée.

Amboise  a dirigé son commerce pendant les dernières2 années.
Avant de commencer ce commerce, Amboise etait un chauffeur et de la cultive.

 Amboise voudrait utiliser cet emprunt pour investir  dans l`epicerie dont il vend des  divers produits

Amboise espère que cet emprunt l’aidera à obtenir un plus grand commerce

Des autres membres de sont groupe  ont besoin d’un emprunt pour tels commerces comme le charbonné le produits divers et cosmetologie

Amboise dit que ses défis  défi principal(s) sont les manques d,achats et trop de personnes lui ont demande le credit

Amboise dit que son but principal  est  d,avoir un  pretter plus d`argent pour obtenir un plus grand commerce avec l`aide de dieu.
texts.en:
Ambroise is the coordinator of his group called "Dieu plus fort." (God is Stronger) He is not married but he has four children. He lives in the northern region of Haiti where electricity is rare and water is very limited. 

Ambroise has been running his business during the past two years. Before beginning this business, he was a driver and farmer.
